Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Valence and Inner-shell Negative Ion Spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
This RUI project studies the interactions of photons with negative ions in two series of experiments. The extra electron in a negative ion is bound predominantly by electron correlation effects and therefore negative ions provide a fertile testing ground for state-of-the-art atomic physics calculations regarding these multi-body interactions. In the first series of experiments, lanthanide negative ions will be investigated on-campus at Denison University using tunable infrared laser light to detach outer-shell electrons. Accurate measurements will be made of the electron affinities and resonance structure of the lanthanides, which are among the least well-understood atomic negative ions. The second series of experiments will investigate inner-shell photodetachment from negative ions, such as selenium and carbon-60, using ultraviolet and X-ray photons at the Advanced Light Source (ALS) synchrotron at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. These experiments continue a series of studies by the PIs investigating short-lived excited states of negative ions and multi-electron decay processes.

The broader impacts of the program include the education of undergraduate students and connections to other scientific fields. The project will enhance the research and teaching infrastructure of Denison University, an undergraduate college. Students will participate in the experiments both on-campus and at the ALS, providing important research experiences for young scientists including technical training in electronics, computers, lasers and optics. The detailed studies of negative ions will yield insights into dynamical many-body interaction, which is a general phenomenon of interest for a broad range of fields in physics, chemistry, and materials science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Negative ions are formed when a neutral atom binds an extra electron, giving the newly formed ion a negative charge.  Negative ions are found in a variety of situations such as lighting discharges, plasma processing and astrophysical applications.  Negative ions provide challenging problems and critical test cases for atomic theory because the added electron is bound to a neutral core, thus the influence of such effects as electron-electron correlation and core polarization is greatly enhanced relative to neutral atoms and positive ions. Many-body effects play an even more important role in inner-shell photoexcitation of negative ions due to core relaxation effects and the interactions of the outgoing electron(s) with both the outer and inner electrons. 

 This project studied the interactions of photons with negative ions in two related series of experiments.  The extra electron in a negative ion is bound predominantly by electron correlation effects and therefore negative ions provide a fertile testing ground for state-of-the-art atomic physics calculations regarding these multi-body interactions.  In the first series of experiments, lanthanide negative ions were investigated on-campus at Denison University using tunable infrared laser light to detach outer-shell electrons.  The ground state photodetachment thresholds of Lanthanide negative ions were measured in order to determine the electron affinity, the initial states of the outer electrons and to search for resonances like those we have discovered in Ce minus. There is currently strong disagreement between theoretical predictions and experimental photoelectron spectroscopy results for these systems. The faculty and student researchers also investigated bound excited states in these ions including bound-bound electric-dipole transitions that exist in the negative ions of Ce and La. We also measured the electron affinities of both indium and arsenic, reducing the uncertainties by factors of about 100 as compared to previous measurements. These experiments provide better input data for use in, for example, the modeling of plasma processing discharges used to manufacture computer chips. The second series of complementary experiments investigated inner-shell photodetachment from O minus, C60 minus and other atomic and molecular negative ions using high energy photons at the Advanced Light Source (ALS) at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. These experiments continue a series of studies by the PIs to investigate the effects of the outer-shell electrons on the detaching inner electron’s wavefunction. The ability to experimentally study inner-shell processes in negative ions has only become possible in recent years with the advent of third-generation synchrotron sources to provide the necessary high brightness and high resolution, however significant progress has been made in this short time. The dynamic multi-electron interactions in the photoexcitation of the highly correlated cores of negative ions continue to challenge the fundamental understanding of atomic structure. Investigations into heavy negative ions and detection of the neutral decay products has helped test the latest theories describing inner-shell photodetachment.
